MATH 2A.title: Calculus with Algebra and Trigonometry
MATH 2A.prereq_description: Qualifying score on the Mathematics Placement Exam.
MATH 2A.comments: Students who have completed Math 34A will only receive 3 units for Math 2A.Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 3A or 3AS or have passed the AP Calculus AB or BC exams.
MATH 2A.description: Math 3A with precalculus: A function approach integrating algebra, trigonometry, and differential calculus. Topics include: one-on-one and onto functions; inverse functions; properties and graphs of polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions; properties and graphs of trigonometric functions; analytic geometry; functions and limits; derivatives; techniques and applications of differentiation; introduction to integration; logarithmic and trigonometric functions.

MATH 2B.title: Calculus with Algebra and Trigonometry
MATH 2B.prereq_description: Mathematics 2A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 2B.comments: Students who have completed Math 34B will only receive 3 units for Math 2B. Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 3B or 3BS or have passed the AP Calculus BC exam.
MATH 2B.description: Math 3B with precalculus: A continued review of relevant topics from precalculus (see Math 2A); integral calculus, including definite and indefinite integrals; techniques of integration, introduction to sequences and series; with applications in mathematics and physics.

MATH 3A.title: Calculus with Applications, First Course
MATH 3A.prereq_description: Qualifying score on the Mathematics Placement Exam.
MATH 3A.comments: Students who have completed Math 34A will only receive 2 units for Math 3A.Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 2A or 3AS or have passed the AP Calculus AB or BC exams.
MATH 3A.description: Differential Calculus including analytic geometry, functions and limits, derivatives, techniques and applications of differentiation; introduction to integration; logarithmic and trigonometric functions.
MATH 3A.recommended_prep: Students with Advanced Placement Credit should contact the   department.

MATH 3B.title: Calculus with Applications, Second Course
MATH 3B.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 3B.comments: Students who have completed Math 34B will only receive 2 units for Math 3B.Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 2B or 3BS or have passed the AP Calculus BC exam.
MATH 3B.description: Integral calculus including definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration; introduction to sequences and series; with applications in mathematics and physics.
MATH 3B.recommended_prep: Students with Advanced Placement Credit should contact the   department.

MATH 4A.title: Linear Algebra with Applications
MATH 4A.prereq_description: Math 2B or 3B or 3BI with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 4A.description: Systems of linear equations, matrix algebra, determinants, vector spaces and subspaces, basis and dimension, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, and orthogonality.

MATH 4AI.title: Inquiry Based Linear Algebra
MATH 4AI.prereq_description: Mathematics 3B or Mathematics 3BI with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 4AI.comments: Misc: Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 3C or Math 4A.
MATH 4AI.description: Honors version of Mathematics 4A. Mathematical inquiry course is developed through problem solving and discovery.

MATH 4B.title: Differential Equations
MATH 4B.prereq_description: Math 4A or Math 4AI with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 4B.description: First and second order differential equations, separation of variables, linear differential equations, systems of first order equations, nonlinear differential equations and stability.

MATH 4BI.title: Inquiry Based Differential Equations
MATH 4BI.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C, 3CI, 4A, or 4AI with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 4BI.comments: Misc: Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 4B or 5A.
MATH 4BI.description: Honors version of Mathematics 4B. Mathematical inquiry course is developed through problem solving and discovery.

MATH 6A.title: Vector Calculus with Applications, First Course
MATH 6A.prereq_description: Mathematics 4A (or 4AI) with a letter grade of C or better.
MATH 6A.description: Calculus of functions of several variables, vector valued functions of one variable, derivative and integrals of vector functions, double and triple integrals, properties and applications of integrals, change of variables.

MATH 6B.title: Vector calculus with Applications, Second Course
MATH 6B.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B (or 4BI) and Mathematics 6A, each with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 6B.description: Scalar and vector fields, integration along paths, integration over surfaces and solid regions, integral theorems of vector calculus, Fourier series, partial differential equations.

MATH 7H.title: Honors Seminar-Calculus
MATH 7H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Mathematics 3A or 3B or 3BI or 3C or 4A or 4AI or 4B
MATH 7H.description: Emphasizing fundamental concepts and applications. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

MATH 8.title: Transition to Higher Mathematics
MATH 8.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI or 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI or 5B or
MATH 8.description: Introduction to the elements of propositional logic, techniques of mathematical proof, and fundamental mathematical structures, including sets, functions, relations, and other topics as time permits. Mastery of this material is essential for students planning to major in mathematics.

MATH 34A.title: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences
MATH 34A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 2A or 3A or 3AS, orare simultaneously enrolled in 2A or 3A, or have passed the AP Calculus AB or BC exams.
MATH 34A.description: Introduction to differential and integral calculus with applications to modeling in the biological sciences.

MATH 34B.title: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences
MATH 34B.prereq_description: Mathematics 2A or 3A or 34A with a grade of C or better.
MATH 34B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Math 2B or 3B or are simultaneously enrolled in 2B or 3B, or have passed the AP Calculus BC exam.
MATH 34B.description: Continued study of differential and integral calculus with differential andintegral calculus with applications. Introduction to mathematical modeling with differential equations. Calculus of several variables including an introduction to partial derivatives.

MATH 94.title: Group Studies in Mathematics
MATH 94.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI or 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI or 5B or 5BI or 5C or 6A or 6AI or 6B with a grade of B or better.
MATH 94.description: Lectures and discussions on special topics. Designed for transfer students only.

MATH 100A.title: Mathematics for Elementary Teaching, I
MATH 100A.comments: Course cannot be used to satisfy any mathematics major or minor requirements.
MATH 100A.description: This class teaches ways to think about and explain elementary school mathematics. Topics include: cultural and base-n number systems, algorithms, elementary number theory, probability, and graphing.

MATH 100B.title: Mathematics for Elementary Teaching, II
MATH 100B.comments: Course cannot be used to satisfy any mathematics major or minor requirements.
MATH 100B.description: Completes the explanation of elementary school mathematics by discussing geometry and algebra. Discusses the pedagogy with the California mathematics framework, the NCTM standards, and "replacement units".

MATH 101A.title: Classical Number Systems
MATH 101A.prereq_description: Math 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 101A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Mathematics 118A.
MATH 101A.description: A conceptual rather than an axiomatic development starting with the natural numbers and progressing through the integral, rational, real, and complex number systems. The historical implications of these developments in number systems. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 101B.title: Mathematical Systems
MATH 101B.prereq_description: Math 101A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 101B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Mathematics 118A.
MATH 101B.description: The theory of operations within rings and fields and the foundations of the real number system. Ideals, quotient rings, and factorization theorems. The history and the historical implications of these developments in mathematical systems. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 102A.title: Modern Euclidean and Noneuclidean Geometry
MATH 102A.prereq_description: Math 8 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 102A.description: Topics in plane and solid geometry. The axioms of pure, euclidean, projective, and noneuclidean geometry. Transformational geometry (isometries, dilitations, involutions, perspectivities, and projectivities). The history and the historical implications of these developments in geometry. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 102B.title: Modern Euclidean and Noneuclidean Geometry
MATH 102B.prereq_description: Math 102A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 102B.description: Topics in plane and solid geometry. The axioms of pure, euclidean, projective, and noneuclidean geometry. Transformational geometry (isometries, dilitations, involutions, perspectivities, and projectivities). The history and the historical implications of these developments in geometry. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 103.title: Introduction to Group Theory
MATH 103.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 103.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Mathematics 111A.
MATH 103.description: Permutation groups, cyclic groups, theory of finite groups, group homomorphisms and isomorphisms, and Abelian groups. Applications to number theory and geometry.

MATH 104A.title: Introduction Into Numerical Analysis
MATH 104A.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B or 4BI, 6A or 6AI, and 6B; or 5A or 5AI, 5B or 5BI and 5C; and Math 117; and, Computer Science 5AA-ZZ or 10 or 8 or 16 or Engineering 3. A grade of C or above is required in all prerequisite courses.
MATH 104A.description: Numerical methods for the solution of nonlinear equations (Newton method), for integration (quadrature formulas and composite integration), and for the initial value problem for ordinary differential equations (Euler and Kutta methods).

MATH 104B.title: Numerical Analysis
MATH 104B.prereq_description: Math 104A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 104B.description: Numerical methods for the solution of systems of linear equations (direct and iteractive methods), and the finite difference methods for boundary value problems for (ordinary and partial) differential equations.

MATH 104C.title: Advanced Topics in Numerical Analysis
MATH 104C.prereq_description: Math 104B with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 104C.description: Topics in approximation theory; numerical methods for finding eigenvalues of a matrix; and advanced topics in numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations.

MATH 108A.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH 108A.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI, 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI; and Math 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 108A.description: Abstract vector spaces and subspaces. Span and linear independence. Basis and dimension. Linear maps. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

MATH 108B.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH 108B.prereq_description: Math 108A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 108B.description: Diagonalization, inner product spaces, projections, least-  squares approximations, invariant factors and elementary divisors, canonical forms, topics from advanced matrix theory, applied linear algebra, and group representation theory.

MATH 108C.title: Matrix Analysis
MATH 108C.prereq_description: Math 108A with a minimum grade of C
MATH 108C.description: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and similarity; Unitary equivalence and normal matrices; QR factorization; Least squares; Singular Value decomposition; Moore-Penrose generalized inverse; Hermitian and symmetric matrices; Variational characterization of eigenvalues; Positive definite matrices; Nonnegative matrices; Perron-Frobenius Theorem.

MATH 109A.title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
MATH 109A.description: An introduction to mathematical logic with applications in computer science and mathematics. Topics include propositional and predicate calculi; models; proof systems, decidability and undecidability, automated theorem-proving, unification, logic programming, and program verification.

MATH 109B.title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
MATH 109B.description: An introduction to mathematical logic with applications in computer science and mathematics. topics include propositional and predicate calculi; models; proof systems, decidability and undecidability, automated theorem-proving, unification, logic programming, and program verification.

MATH 109C.title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
MATH 109C.description: An introduction to mathematical logic with applications in computer science and mathematics. Topics include propositional and predicate calculi; models; proof systems, decidability and undecidability, automated theorem-proving, unification, logic programming, and program verification.

MATH 111A.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra
MATH 111A.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 and 108A with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 111A.description: An introduction to algebraic structures with an emphasis on groups.

MATH 111B.title: Abstract Algebra
MATH 111B.prereq_description: Math 111A with a minimum grade of C.

MATH 111C.title: Abstract Algebra
MATH 111C.prereq_description: Math 111B with a minimum grade of C.

MATH 113.title: Non-euclidean Geometry
MATH 113.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 113.description: An introduction to hyperbolic geometry with some discussion of other non-  euclidean systems.

MATH 114.title: Computational Tools for Numerical Analysis
MATH 114.prereq_description: Math 6B, Math 8, and Math 108A or Math 117 each with a letter grade of
MATH 114.description: Introduction to programming with specific examples in scientific computing. The algorithms used will be analyzed in detail in Math 104A-B-C. The emphasis will be the translation of numerical algorithms into actual working code.
MATH 114.recommended_prep: At least one quarter of programming experience.

MATH 115A.title: Introduction to Number Theory
MATH 115A.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 115A.description: Divisibility, congruences, primitive roots an indices, quadratic residues and the quadratic reciprocity law, number-theoretic functions, Diophantine equations, the distribution of primes, number-theorhetic methods in cryptography, quadratic forms, continued fractions, and the approximation of real numbers, algebraic number theory, partitions.

MATH 115B.title: Introduction to Number Theory
MATH 115B.prereq_description: Math 115A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 115B.description: Divisibility, congruences, primitive roots and indices, quadratic residues and the quadratic reciprocity law, number-theoretic functions, Diophantine equations, the distribution of primes, number-theoretic methods in cryptography, quadratic forms, continued fractions, and the approximation of real numbers, algebraic number theory, partitions.

MATH 115C.title: Topics in Number Theory
MATH 115C.prereq_description: Math 115B with a minimum grade of C or consent of instructor.
MATH 115C.description: Selected topics in number theory at the direction of the instructor.

MATH 116.title: Combinatorial Analysis
MATH 116.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 116.description: Elementary counting principles, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, the principle of inclusion and exclusion, distributions and partitions, systems of distinct representatives, applications to computation.

MATH 117.title: Methods of Analysis
MATH 117.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 or PSTAT 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 117.description: Introduction to methods of proof in analysis. topics include limits, sequences and series, continuity, compactness, as well as other topics. This course is intended to follow Mathematics 8 and to introduce students to the level of sophistication of upper-division mathematics.

MATH 118A.title: Introduction to Real Analysis
MATH 118A.prereq_description: Mathematics 5A or 5AI and 5B or 5BI; or 4B or 4BI and 6A or 6AI; and
MATH 118A.description: The real number system, elements of set theory, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, implicit function theorems, convergence processes, and special topics.

MATH 118B.title: Introduction to Real Analysis
MATH 118B.prereq_description: Math 118A and 108B with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 118B.description: The real number system, elements of set theory, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, implicit function theorems, convergence processes, and special topics.

MATH 118C.title: Introduction to Real Analysis
MATH 118C.prereq_description: Math 118B with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 118C.description: The real number system, elements of set theory, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, implicit function theorems, convergence processes, and special topics.

MATH 119A.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 119A.prereq_description: Mathematics 5A or 5AI and 5B or 5BI with a minimum grade of C; or 4B or 4BI and 6A or 6AI with a minimum grade of C; and Math 8 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 119A.description: Existence, uniqueness, and stability; the geometry of phase space; linear systems and hyperbolicity; maps and diffeomorphisms.

MATH 119B.title: Chaotic Dynamics and Bifurcation Theory
MATH 119B.prereq_description: Mathematics 6B and Math 119A, each with a minimum grade of C
MATH 119B.description: Hyperbolic structure and chaos; center manifolds; bifurcation theory; and the Feigenbaum and Ruelle-Takens cascades to strange attractors.

MATH 122A.title: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
MATH 122A.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B or 4BI and 6A with a minimum grade of C; and Math 8 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 122A.description: Complex numbers, functions, differentiability, series extensions of elementary functions, complex integration, calculus of residues, conformal maps, mapping functions, applications.

MATH 122B.title: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
MATH 122B.prereq_description: Math 122A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 122B.description: Complex numbers, functions, differentiability, series extensions of elementary functions, complex integration, calculus of residues, conformal maps, mapping functions, applications.

MATH 124A.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 124A.prereq_description: Math 4B or 4BI, 6A, and 6B with a minimum grade of C; and Math 8 with a minimum grade of C.

MATH 124B.title: Fourier Series and Numerical Methods
MATH 124B.prereq_description: Math 4B or 4BI, and 6A, and 6B with a minimum grade of C; and 124A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 124B.description: Fourier series; generalized functions; and numerical methods.

MATH 132A.title: Introduction to Operations Research
MATH 132A.prereq_description: Math 6A and Math 108A, both with a grade of C or above. Computer Science 8 or 16, or Engineering 3 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 132A.description: Linear programming, the simplex method, duality, applications to the transportation and assignment problems, sensitivity analysis, problem formulation.

MATH 132B.title: Introduction to Operations Research
MATH 132B.prereq_description: Mathematics 117 and 132A, each with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 132B.description: Network analysis: shortest route, minimal spanning tree and maximal flow problems; PERT including the critical path method; dynamic programming; game theory; integer programming, nonlinear programming.

MATH 137A.title: Graph and Network Theory
MATH 137A.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B or 4BI; and  Math 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 137A.description: Elements of graph and network theory including paths, circuits, trees, coloring, planarity, matching theory, Hall's theorem, applications to scheduling theory, flows in networks, Menger's theorem, and other topics as time permits.

MATH 137B.title: Graph and Network Theory
MATH 137B.prereq_description: Math 137A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 137B.description: Elements of graph and network theory including paths, circuits, trees, coloring, planarity, matching theory, Hall's theorem, applications to scheduling theory, flows in networks, Menger's theorem, and other topics as time permits.

MATH 145.title: Introduction to Topology
MATH 145.prereq_description: Math 8 with a C or better. Either Math 108A or Math 117 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 145.description: Metric spaces, continuity, compactness, classification of surfaces, Euler characteristics, and fundamental groups. Additional topics at the discretion of the instructor.

MATH 147A.title: Introductory Differential Geometry
MATH 147A.prereq_description: Math 6A with a minimum grade of C; and Math 108A or 117 with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 147A.description: Curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space, first and second fundamental forms, Gaussian and mean curvature, geodesics, Gauss-Bonnet theorem, and non-Euclidean geometry.

MATH 147B.title: Introductory Differential Geometry
MATH 147B.prereq_description: Mathematics 147A with a minimum grade of C.
MATH 147B.description: Curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space, first and second fundamental forms, Gaussian and mean curvature, geodesics, Gauss-Bonnet theorem, and non-  Euclidean geometry.

MATH 170.title: Introduction to Mathematical Finance
MATH 170.prereq_description: PSTAT 120A-B and 160A, all completed with a minimum grade of C or better.
MATH 170.description: Describes mathematical methods for estimating and evaluating asset pricing models, equilibrium and derivative pricing, options, bonds, and the term-structure of interest rates. Also introduces finance optimization models for risk management and financial engineering.

MATH 181A.prereq_description: Math 8 with a minimum grade of C
MATH 181A.description: Focuses on the representations, strategies, and language learners use to conceptualize and develop fundamental ideas of mathematics. Includes advanced mathematical problem solving and its implications for teaching and learning at the secondary level. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 181B.title: Advanced Problem Solving in Mathematical, Historical, and   Pedagogical Contexts
MATH 181B.prereq_description: Math 181A or ED 134 with a minimum grade of C
MATH 181B.description: Continuation of Math 181A or ED 134. Focuses on the representations, strategies, and language learners use to conceptualize and develop fundamental ideas of mathematics. Includes advanced mathematical problem solving and its implications for teaching and learning at the secondary level. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 182.title: History of Mathematics
MATH 182.prereq_description: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.
MATH 182.description: An examination of the major achievements in mathematical thinking throughout history. Topics may include the history of numerical systems in early civilizations, the development of formal proof, mathematical contributions from diverse populations and the impact of technological innovations on mathematics. Especially suitable for prospective middle and high school teachers.

MATH 190.title: Special Topics in Mathematics
MATH 190.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI or 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI or 5B or 5BI or 5C or 6A or 6AI or 6B with a grade of B or better. Concurrent enrollment in Math 94.
MATH 190.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
MATH 190.description: Information about the special topics to be presented may be obtained from the office of the Department of Mathematics. Designed for transfer students only.

MATH 193.title: Internship in Mathematics
MATH 193.comments: May be repeated for credit up to a maximum of four units. Credit will not be given toward upper-division Mathematics major requirements.
MATH 193.description: Faculty sponsored academic internship in industrial or research firms.

MATH 194GS.title: Group Studies for Advanced Students
MATH 194GS.comments: Enrollment normally limited to 12 or fewer students.
MATH 194GS.description: Participants will select a math-related book or papers, read the section before the next meeting and discuss reading at the meeting. Readings may include biographies of mathematicians, histories or popularizations of mathematics, textbooks, and readings in mathematical physics or biology.

MATH 197A.title: Senior Thesis
MATH 197A.prereq_description: Open to senior majors only; consent of department and instructor.
MATH 197A.comments: Up to four units may apply to the major. Up to eight units total in all Mathematics 197/199RA courses may apply toward the major. Students must have aminimum overall grade-point average of 3.0 and a 3.5 or better grade-point-average in the major.
MATH 197A.description: Independent research under the supervision of a faculty member which will result in a senior thesis. Student will concentrate on reading and gathering material for a thesis.

MATH 197B.title: Senior Thesis
MATH 197B.prereq_description: Mathematics 197A. Open to senior majors only; consent of department and instructor.
MATH 197B.comments: Students must have a minimum overall grade-point average of 3.0 and a 3.5 or better grade-point average in the major. Up to four units may apply towards the major.
MATH 197B.description: Independent research under the supervision of a faculty member which will result in a senior thesis. Student will concentrate on writing a thesis.

MATH 199.title: Independent Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in math; consent of instructor and department.
MATH 199.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s). Limit of 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all independent studies courses (98/99/99RA/198/199/199AA-ZZ) combined.  Only 8 units in Math 197/199AA-ZZ courses may apply to the major.
MATH 199.description: Coursework consists of academic research supervised by a faculty member on a topic not available in established course offerings.

MATH 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance
MATH 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in math; consent of instructor and department.
MATH 199RA.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s). Limit of 5 units per quarter and 30 units total allowed in all independent studies courses (98/99/99RA/198/199/199AA-ZZ) combined. Only 8 units in Math 197/199AA-ZZ courses may apply to the major.
MATH 199RA.description: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.

MATH 201A.title: Real Analysis
MATH 201A.description: Measure theory and integration. Point set topology. Principles of functional analysis. Lp-spaces. The Riesz representation theorem. Topics in real and functional analysis.

MATH 201B.title: Real Analysis
MATH 201B.description: Measure theory and integration. Point set topology. Principles of functional analysis. Lp-spaces. The Riesz representation theorem. Topics in real and functional analysis.

MATH 201C.title: Real Analysis
MATH 201C.description: Measure theory and integration. Point set topology. Principles of functional analysis. Lp-spaces. The Riesz representation theorem. Topics in real and functional analysis.

MATH 202A.title: Complex Analysis
MATH 202A.description: Analytic functions. Complex integration. Cauchy's theorem. Series and product developments. Entire functions. Conformal mappings. Topics in complex analysis.

MATH 202B.title: Complex Analysis
MATH 202B.description: Analytic functions. Complex integration. Cauchy's theorem. Series and product developments. Entire functions. Conformal mappings. Topics in complex analysis.

MATH 202C.title: Complex Analysis
MATH 202C.description: Analytic functions. Complex integration. Cauchy's theorem. Series and product developments. Entire functions. Conformal mappings. Topics in complex analysis.

MATH 206A.title: Matrix Analysis and Computation
MATH 206A.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211A, ME 210A, ECE 210A, Geology 251A, and Chemical Engineering 211A.
MATH 206A.description: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.

MATH 206B.title: Numerical Simulation
MATH 206B.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211B, ME 210B, ECE 210B, Geology 251B, and Chemical Engineering 211B.
MATH 206B.description: Linear multistep methods and Runge-Kutta methods for ordinary differential equations: stability, order and convergence. Stiffness. Differential algebraic equations. Numerical solution of boundary value problems.

MATH 206C.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite   Difference Methods
MATH 206C.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211C, ME 210C, ECE 210C, Geology 251C, and Chemical Engineering 211C.
MATH 206C.description: Finite difference methods for hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic PDE's, with application to problems in science and engineering. Convergence, consistency, order and stability of finite difference methods. Dissipation and dispersion. Finite volume methods. Software design and adaptivity.

MATH 206D.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations - Finite   Element Methods
MATH 206D.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211D, ME 210D, ECE 210D, Geology 251D, and Chemical Engineering 211D.
MATH 206D.description: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic partial differential equations, with application to problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.

MATH 214A.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 214A.description: Existence, uniqueness, and stability; the geometry of phase space; linear systems and hyperbolicity; maps and diffeomorphisms.

MATH 214B.title: Chaotic Dynamics and Bifurcation Theory
MATH 214B.description: Hyberbolic structure and chaos; center manifolds; bifurcation theory; and the Feigenbaum and Ruelle-Takens cascades to strange attractors.

MATH 215B.title: Fourier Series and Numerical Methods
MATH 215B.description: Fourier series; generalized functions; and numerical methods.

MATH 220A.title: Modern Algebra
MATH 220A.description: Group theory, ring and module theory, field theory, Galois theory, other topics.

MATH 220B.title: Modern Algebra
MATH 220B.description: Group theory, ring and module theory, field theory, Galois theory, other topics.

MATH 220C.title: Modern Algebra
MATH 220C.description: Group theory, ring and module theory, field theory, Galois theory, other topics.

MATH 221A.title: Foundations of Topology
MATH 221A.description: Metric spaces, topological spaces, continuity, Hausdorff condition, compactness, connectedness, product spaces, quotient spaces. Other topics as time allows.

MATH 221B.title: Homotopy Theory
MATH 221B.description: Homotopy groups, exact sequences, fiber spaces, covering spaces, van Kampen Theorem.

MATH 221C.title: Differential Topology
MATH 221C.description: Topological manifolds, differentiable manifolds, transversality, tangent bundles, Borsuk-Ulam theorem, orientation and intersection number, Lefschetz fixed point theorem, vector fields.

MATH 225A.title: Topics in Number Theory
MATH 225A.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.

MATH 225B.title: Topics in Number Theory
MATH 225B.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.

MATH 225C.title: Topics in Number Theory
MATH 225C.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.

MATH 227A.title: Advanced Topics in Geometric and Algebraic Topology
MATH 227A.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.
MATH 227A.description: Topics, varying from year to year, include piecewise linear and differential topology, manifolds, fiber bundles and fiber spaces, homotopy theory, and spectral sequences.

MATH 227B.title: Advanced Topics in Geometric and Algebraic Topology
MATH 227B.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.
MATH 227B.description: Topics, varying from year to year, include piecewise linear and differential topology, manifolds, fiber bundles and fiber spaces, homotopy theory, and spectral sequences.

MATH 227C.title: Advanced Topics in Geometric and Algebraic Topology
MATH 227C.comments: May be repeated for credit with instructor and department approval.
MATH 227C.description: Topics, varying from year to year, include piecewise linear and differential topology, manifolds, fiber bundles and fiber spaces, homotopy theory, and spectral sequences.

MATH 228A.title: Functional Analysis
MATH 228A.description: Topics in functional analysis such as operators on Hilbert space, convex analysis, fixed point theorems, distribution theory, unbounded operators.

MATH 228B.title: Functional Analysis
MATH 228B.description: Topics in functional analysis such as operators on Hilbert space, convex analysis, fixed point theorems, distribution theory, unbounded operators.

MATH 231A.title: Lie Groups and Lie Algebras
MATH 231A.description: Differentiable manifolds, definition and examples of lie groups, lie group-lie algebra correspondence, nilpotent and solvable lie algebras, classification of semi-simple lie algebras over the complexes, representations of lie groups and lie algebras, special topics.

MATH 231B.title: Lie Groups and Lie Algebras
MATH 231B.description: Differentiable manifolds, definition and examples of lie groups, lie group-lie algebra correspondence, nilpotent and solvable lie algebras, classification of semi-simple lie algebras over the complexes, representations of lie groups and lie algebras, special topics.

MATH 232A.title: Algebraic Topology
MATH 232A.description: Singular homology and cohomology, exact sequences, Hurewicz theorem, Poincare duality.

MATH 232B.title: Algebraic Topology
MATH 232B.description: Singular homology and cohomology, exact sequences, Hurewicz theorem, Poincare duality.

MATH 236A.title: Homological Algebra
MATH 236A.description: Algebraic construction of homology and cohomology theories, aimed at applications to topology, geometry, groups and rings. Special emphasis on hom and tensor functors; projective, injective and flat modules; exact sequences; chain complexes; derived functors, in particular, ext and tor.

MATH 236B.title: Homological Algebra
MATH 236B.description: Algebraic construction of homology and cohomology theories, aimed at applications to topology, geometry, groups and rings. Special emphasis on hom and tensor functors; projective, injective and flat modules; exact sequences; chain complexes; derived functors, in particular, ext and tor.

MATH 237A.title: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 237A.description: Affine/projective varieties, Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, morphisms of varieties, rational maps, dimension, singular/nonsingular points, blowing up of varieties, tanent spaces, divisors, differentials, Riemann-Roch theorem. Special topics may include: elliptic curves, intersection numbers, Bezout's theorem, Max Noether's theorem.

MATH 237B.title: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 237B.description: Affine/projective varieties, Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, morphisms of varieties, rational maps, dimension, singular/nonsingular points, blowing up of varieties, tangent spaces, divisors, differentials, Riemann-Roch theorem. Special topics may include: elliptic curves, intersection numbers,Bezout's theorem, Max Noether's theorem.

MATH 237C.title: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 237C.description: Affine/projective varieties, Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, morphisms of varieties, rational maps, demension, singular/nonsingular points, blowing up of varieties, tanent spaces, divisors, differentials Riemann-Roch theorem. Special topics may include: elliptic curves, intersection numbers, Bezout's theorem, Max Noether's theorem.

MATH 240A.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry and Riemannian Geometry
MATH 240A.description: Topics include geometry of surfaces, manifolds, differential forms, Lie groups, Riemannian manifolds, Levi-Civita connection and curvature, curvature and topology, Hodge theory. Additional topics such as bundles and characteristic classes, spin structures, and Dirac operator, comparison theorems in Riemannian geometry.

MATH 240B.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry and Riemannian Geometry
MATH 240B.description: Topics include geometry of surfaces, manifolds, differential forms, Lie groups, Riemannian manifolds, Levi-Civita connection and curvature, curvature and topology, Hodge theory. Additional topics such as bundles and characteristic classes, spin structures, and Dirac operator, comparison theorems in Riemannian geometry.

MATH 240C.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry and Riemannian Geometry
MATH 240C.description: Topics include geometry of surfaces, manifolds, differential forms, Lie groups, Riemannian manifolds, Levi-Civita connection and curvature, curvature and topology, Hodge theory. Additional topics such as bundles and characteristic classes, spin structures, and Dirac operator, comparison theorems in Riemannian geometry.

MATH 241A.title: Topics in Differential Geometry
MATH 241A.description: Various topics are covered including sectional curvature and Ricci curvature, minimal submanifolds, Atiyah-Singer index theorem and eta invariant, Einstein manifold, symplectic geometry, geometry of gauge theories, geometric PDE, Morse theory and Floer theory.

MATH 241B.title: Topics in Differential Geometry
MATH 241B.description: Various topics are covered including sectional curvature and Ricci curvature, minimal submanifolds, Atiyah-Singer index theorem and eta invariant, Einstein manifold, symplectic geometry, geometry of gauge theories, geometric PDE, Morse theory and Floer theory.

MATH 241C.title: Topics in Differential Geometry
MATH 241C.description: Various topics are covered including sectional curvature and Ricci curvature, minimal submanifolds, Atiyah-Singer index theorem and eta invariant, Einstein manifold, symplectic geometry, geometry of gauge theories, geometric PDE, Morse theory and Floer theory.

MATH 243A.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 243A.description: Existence and stability of solutions, Floquet theory, Poincare-Bendixson theorem, invariant manifolds, existence and stability of periodic solutions, Bifurcation theory and normal forms, hyperbolic structure and chaos, Feigenbaum period-doubling cascade, Ruelle-Takens cascade.

MATH 243B.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 243B.description: Existance and stability of solutions, Floq uet theory, Poincare-Bendixson theorem, invariant manifolds, existence and stability of periodic solutions, Bifurcation theory and normal forms, hyperbolic structure and chaos, Feigenbaum period-doubling cascade, Ruelle-Takens cascade.

MATH 243C.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 243C.description: Existance and stability of solutions, Floquet theory, Poincare-Bendixson theorem, invariant manifolds, existence and stability of periodic solutions, Bifurcation theory and normal forms, hyperbolic structure and chaos, Feigenbaum period-doubling cascade, Ruelle-Takens cascade.

MATH 246A.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 246A.description: First-order nonlinear equations; the Cauchy problem, elements of distribution theory an Sobolev spaces; the heat, wave, and Laplace equations; additional topics such as quasilinear symmetric hyperbolic systems, elliptic regularity theory.

MATH 246B.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 246B.description: First-order nonlinear equations; the Cauchy problem, elements of distribution theory and Sobolev spaces; the heat, wave, and Laplace equations; additional topics such as quasilinear symmetric hyperbolic systems, elliptic regularity theory.

MATH 246C.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 246C.description: First-order nonlinear equations; the Cauchy problem, elements of distribution theory and Sobolev spaces; the heat, wave, and Laplace equations; additional topics such as quasilinear symmetric hyperbolic systems, ellipitic regularity theory.

MATH 260AAZZ.title: Seminars in Mathematics
MATH 260AAZZ.description: Topics in algebra, analysis, applied mathematics, combinatorial mathematics, functional analysis, geometry, statistics, topology, by means of lectures and informal conferences with members of staff.

MATH 500.title: Teaching Assistant Practicum
MATH 500.prereq_description: Appointment as teaching assistant and departmental approval.
MATH 500.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
MATH 500.description: Supervised teaching of undergraduate mathematics courses.

MATH 501.title: Teaching Assistant Training
MATH 501.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
MATH 501.description: Consideration of ideas about the process of learning mathematics and discussion of approaches to teaching.

MATH 502.title: Teaching Associate Practicum
MATH 502.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.

MATH 510.title: Reading for Area Examinations
MATH 510.prereq_description: Enrollment in M.A. or Ph.D. program. Consent of instructor.

MATH 596AAZZ.title: Directed Reading and Research
MATH 596AAZZ.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
MATH 596AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit. Only 8 units total in all Mathematics 596, 598,599 courses may be applied toward the degree.

MATH 598AAZZ.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
MATH 598AAZZ.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
MATH 598AAZZ.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.

MATH 599AAZZ.title: Dissertation Preparation
MATH 599AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit. Only 8 units total in all Mathematics 596, 598,599 courses may apply toward degree.
